title: @Riot, If Cass can't be a poison mage, can you make one?
body:
Like an actual DoT poison based mage champion built around doing poison DoT to enemies and slowly killing her victims.

**EDIT: **To all of those saying Singed or Teemo

Singed is a Tank and is not very reliable with poisoning enemies. Dependent on people running into him, and he's not that good right now, especially higher up.

Teemo is a Marksman and he poisons with auto attacks. His shrooms are kind of poison like, but they nerfed them pretty good, and again his poison isn't reliable.

We want a mage that uses spells that are reliable to hit and that do damage over time. Not a trap hamster. Not a poison trail chemist. An actual poison mage.

replies.body: The Cass changes are still based around poisoning enemies doing little to no damage and spamming E. I'm pretty sure most of the community (including me) want an actual poison mage who does damage with the poison, not activating the rest of her kit by poisoning target champion.

True, but the big difference between damage over time and burst damage is that it will most probably offer you much better rewards/less risks.

Most of the spells that deal damage over time have higher amounts of damage or are easier to apply in general ( think about Malzahar, Swain a bit).

Some of them actually offer utility ( Brand's passive for combo's, Swain's E enchants his damage, the current Cass uses her poisons to spam her E).

The idea is, despite the lack of burst damage, and the unreliability of getting kills, damage-over-time-abilities get compensated in other areas and have some strengths over the burst-damage-abilities.

I think part of the big problem a pure DoT character faces is that they are almost impossible to balance. Either they don't deal enough damage or deal damage quickly enough to be relevant, or they deal so much damage that killing your opponent becomes inevitable and they become OP.

If a champion doesn't deal too much damage, he/she may get utility over the damage (like Anivia's ultimate?).

About the too high amount of damage problem, it can be easily solved by making that character have more weaknesses.

Take Malzahar for example. All his kit is pure DoT, only his Q being a burst ability. 

His base damages and ratios are insane, his E poke can be devastating and a perfect combo with his ult can kill almost anyone.

Is he powerful? Yes. He is deadly? Totally! Is he OP? Not really. He has lots of ways to play around him, his range and his low-mobility. He can 1v1 almost anyone, but when there are two people, he is forced to play a lot safer.

So, if the DoT user has lots of damage, he/she will most probably be balanced in some other areas, to compensate the enormous amount of damage. I personally would prefer to see more DoT users that offer more utility than damage, so that they show a more interesting feature than "I will deal more damage than you! Just wait 5 seconds!!!".

I'm not sure Malzahar is exactly an exemplar of a well balanced DoT character. That being said, Malz has a lot of issues that aren't related to his DoT potential, so it's tough to discuss his damage over time in a vacuum. 

And I agree about seeing more utility than straight damage. And those characters I think are easier to work with. But at that point, are they a pure DoT character or are they a utility mage that happens to have some DoT abilities? I don't think it's impossible to balance out a character that can deal damage over time, I think it's incredibly difficult to balance them when their sole focus is on dealing damage.

Despite having three damage over time abilities, Malzahar isn't a dot mage. He's not about using damage over time to whittle his opponent down, his playstyle is about bursting them down. He's more like an AP Yi who, despite dealing his damage as DPS with his autos, is more about bursting someone down.

Swain, while not being as much about the burst rotation as Malzahar, still functions more like a traditional mage in that his trading patterns are similar to a mage that doesn't have dots. Only his ult is really used as a dot for sustaining in a teamfight.

Teemo is the only one there that is really about damage over time and slowly weakening someone by poking them with autos and his E poison. Singed has a poison playstyle too in that his pattern is about making people chase him while they slowly choke on his fumes and die.
